name: 2-[3-(2-methoxyphenyl)-5,6-dihydro[1,2,4]triazolo[3,4-b][1,3,4]thiadiazol-6-yl]phenol
source: Karthikeyan M.; Glen R.C.; Bender A. General melting point prediction based on a diverse compound dataset and artificial neural networks. J. Chem. Inf. Model.; 2005; 45(3); 581-3683

name: 2-[3-(2-methoxyphenyl)-5,6-dihydro[1,2,4]triazolo[3,4-b][1,3,4]thiadiazol-6-yl]phenol
source: Karthikeyan M.; Glen R.C.; Bender A. General melting point prediction based on a diverse compound dataset and artificial neural networks. J. Chem. Inf. Model.; 2005; 45(3); 581-3683
Reason: The compound 2-[3-(2-methoxyphenyl)-5,6-dihydro[1,2,4]triazolo[3,4-b][1,3,4]thiadiazol-6-yl]phenol can be dissected into several distinct functional groups that affect its melting point. The base structure contains two benzene rings, which provide a starting point similar to biphenyl, with a melting point of around 70 degrees Celsius. The methoxy group (–OCH3) typically raises a melting point due to increased molecular weight and dispersion forces slightly, but its electronegative oxygen can form intermolecular hydrogen bonds, which in biphenyl compounds leads to an increase of about 20 degrees Celsius. The triazolothiadiazole unit, which contains nitrogen and sulfur atoms, considerably raises the melting point due to increased rigidity, additional nitrogen-based hydrogen bonding, and larger molecular weight; such heterocyclic substitutions can be expected to increase melting points by 100-120 degrees Celsius. Finally, the additional phenol (–OH) group contributes significantly to the melting point due to the capability of hydrogen bonding; the presence of a hydroxyl group on a benzene ring can raise the melting point by approximately 20-30 degrees Celsius.
Prediction: Starting with the base biphenyl value of 70, adding 20 for the methoxy group, 100 for the heterocyclic portion, and 20 for the hydroxyl group, we estimate the melting point to be 210 degrees Celsius, which is close to the actual value of 205 degrees Celsius.
